description.narrative: Addressing HIV epidemics in the Country to reduce HIV incidence and prevalence and improve linkages to HIV testing among key population

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1. Percentage of men who have sex with men reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services 2. Percentage of men who have sex with men that have received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results 3. Percentage of female sex workers reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services 4. Percentage of female sex workers that have received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results 5. Number of people who were tested for HIV and received their results during the reporting period 6. Percentage of people living with HIV currently receiving antiretroviral therapy 7. Percentage of people living with HIV and on ART, who have a suppressed viral load at 12 months (<1000 copies/ml) 8. Percentage of ART sites that had stock-out of any antiretroviral drugs during the reporting period 9. Percentage of HIV-positive new and relapse TB patients on ART during TB treatment 10. Percentage of people living with HIV newly enrolled in HIV care started on TB preventive therapy 11. Percentage of HMIS or other routine reporting units submitting timely reports according to national guidelines

1. 8,241 (108%) of men who have sex with men were reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services 2. 3672 (60%) of men who have sex with men received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results 3. 10207 (120%) of female sex workers were reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services 4. 4702 (83%) of female sex workers received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results 5. 87844 (50%) people who were tested for HIV and received their results during the reporting period 6. 9691 (83%) people living with HIV were currently receiving antiretroviral therapy 7. 61.2 % of people living with HIV and on ART, had a suppressed viral load at 12 months (<1000 copies/ml) 8. 0% of ART sites had stock-out of any antiretroviral drugs during the reporting period 9. 81% of HIV-positive new and relapse TB patients on ART during TB treatment 10. 21 % Percentage of people living with HIV were newly enrolled in HIV care started on TB preventive therapy 11. 71% of HMIS or other routine reporting units submitted timely reports according to national guidelines

1. 7,882 of men who have sex with men reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services 2. 6,305 of men who have sex with men that have received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results 3. 7073 of female sex workers reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services 4. 7,298 of female sex workers that have received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results 5. 219,368 people who were tested for HIV and received their results during the reporting period 6. 16800 people living with HIV currently receiving antiretroviral therapy 7. 90% of people living with HIV and on ART, who have a suppressed viral load at 12 months (<1000 copies/ml) 8. 0% of ART sites that had stock-out of any antiretroviral drugs during the reporting period 9. 100% of HIV-positive new and relapse TB patients on ART during TB treatment 10. 100%Percentage of people living with HIV newly enrolled in HIV care started on TB preventive therapy 11. 100% of HMIS or other routine reporting units submitting timely reports according to national guidelines

The impact of COVID-19 pandemic and lockdown led to complete disruption of provision of HIV services to KPs and the general population. Health care providers and health personnel working for the HIV programs at States and at Federal Ministry of Health (FMOH) level were released from work for a prolonged period of time through a Ministerial circular released in March 2020. When the services were resumed, in June 2020, some health care workers were diagnosed with COVID-19, leading to closure of most of health facilities. Lack of PPE for health care providers affected their willingness to continue providing services, resulting in reduced number of people accessing HIV services. In some states, security situation contributed to closure of facilities (mainly in Darfur region and South Kordofan)
Results reported by end of September are indicated below:
1. 495 men who have sex with men were reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services 2. 360 men who have sex with men received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results 3. 363 of female sex workers were reached with HIV prevention programs - defined package of services 4. 328 of female sex workers received an HIV test during the reporting period and know their results 5. 51,247people who were tested for HIV and received their results during the reporting period 6. 11,006 people living with HIV currently receiving antiretroviral therapy 7. 65 % of people living with HIV and on ART, had a suppressed viral load at 12 months (<1000 copies/ml) 8. 0% of ART sites had stock-out of any antiretroviral drugs during the reporting period 9. 98 % of HIV-positive new and relapse TB patients were started on ART during TB treatment 10. 44%Percentage of people living with HIV newly enrolled in HIV care started on TB preventive therapy 11. 78 % of HMIS or other routine reporting units submitted timely reports according to national guidelines
The project has been operationally closed and no activities in 2021.
The project has been operationally closed and no activities in 2021.
